awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Biochemical, Genetic, Metabolic and Isotopic Constraints on an Ancient Thiobiosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
Chemical bonds between phosphorus and oxygen are important in building DNA and RNA, and also in supplying modern cells with energy. It is not known, however, whether the first life forms had the same chemistry, and early life in particular may have run on sulfur instead of phosphorus. This project will work backwards from the traces of this sulfur-based chemistry in modern life to reconstruct the role of sulfur-oxygen bonds in early ecosystems. Predictions made from this approach will be compared to the carbon and sulfur isotope record in  >2.5 billion year old rocks. We will use the astrobiology social media platform (SAGANet) for the conversations with public about this project and other studies of evolution of life on Earth.  
 
Phosphate esters, such as nucleotide triphosphates, diphosphates, and pyrophosphate, are the central component of energy metabolism in all living cells. It is not known, however, whether they were of similar paramount importance at the origin of life or in the first cells, or whether another kind of chemistry was playing the same role there. Considerations from geochemistry, molecular evolution, and systems biology imply that thioesters - high-energy bonds based on sulfur instead of phosphorus - may have supplied energy in the first metabolisms on Earth. This project will develop a broad and detailed understanding of the natural history of thioester utilization, working backwards to reconstruct ancient biochemistry from contemporary metabolism, and simultaneously examining pre-biological chemistries that can couple thioester formation and degradation. These two lines of study will allow the research team to infer the carbon and sulfur isotopic signatures of important metabolic pathways in a putative early thiobiosphere, and test whether these signatures are preserved in the >2.5 billion year old geological record. The results of this project should be of broad interest, and the project will engage with the scientific community and the public through journal publications as well as an established astrobiology social media platform (SAGANet). Select high school serving communities traditionally underrepresented in science will be reached through semester-long programs led by SAGANet graduate student mentors and facilitated by the investigators of this project.

por.por_cntn:
This project was part of joint NSF / NASA research proposal call which asked researchers to gather and discuss what they do not know, but want to understand. The specific focus was on the origin of life, and the joint project was known as an IDEAS Lab. During the initial gathering of researchers, one member (Shawn Erin McGlynn) suggested that sulfur containing compounds known as thioesters might hold important clues to the origin of life, but knowledge about these compounds was too limited to understand this. Around this idea, a number of researchers gathered, working across multiple disciplines to address the question: what roles did sulfur containing thioesters have in the origin and evolution of life?

During the project period, laboratory chemistry experiments were performed which revealed a previously un-known energy transfer reaction between these thioester compounds called an ester exchange.

By analyzing thousands of microbial genomes, we tried to see if we could find traces of sulfur chemistry in the earliest organisms on Earth. We found that the signal of microbial metabolic evolution has become cloudy over the long period that life has been on Earth, and that only limited insights can be gained from this approach. 

A significant amount of effort was taken to mentor young scientists, and in 2020 a post doctoral researcher was hired to assist with the project goals, and two early career collaborators were invited to work together towards the project goals. In this work, we specifically sought to gain an understanding protein fold evolution in relationship to metabolic innovation through time. 

We also investigated two possible key environments which may have led to the origin of life through carbon-sulfur chemistry: hydrothermal vents and atmospheric chemistry processes. Hydrothermal vents are known to support life independently of surface processes and the photosynthetic reactions that we humans rely on, and are thought to have created conditions appropriate for the origin of life. We revealed a new type of chemistry where chemical reactants are separated by a hydrothermal vent mineral and the mineral itself is reactive towards both. By using  this chemical reactor, we showed for the first time the reduction of carbon dioxide using a pH gradient of the same type that exists at hydrothermal vents. In atmospheric chemistry work, we have identified a large number of carbon-sulfur containing molecules which may have been incorporated into early metabolism and kickstarted key processes. 

Societal outcomes were pursued through communication with the public, and we collaborated with members of the Blue Marble Space Institute of Science to enhance the Sagan net website https://www.saganet.org/ as well as to interview a number of scientists; these interviews are now part of the Sagan net site.
